data.question: Find the error in the following program: main() { int m; char g; switch(m) { case 3: grade="P";break; case : grade="Q";break; case 1: grade="R";break; default: grade="S";break; } } What will be the output of the program?
data.op2: switch statement cannot have more than three labels

data.question: How many times will the following loop be executed? ch = ‘b’ while (ch > = ‘a’ && ch <= ‘z’)

Study the following ‘C’ program #include <stdio.h> void main () { int a = , b = 5; switch (a/a % b) { case 1 : a = a-b; case 2 : a = a+b; case 3 : a = a*b; case 4 : a = a/b; default : a = a; } } One the execution of above program, what will be the variable a?
A switch statement is used to
data.op2: Switch between function in a programchar
data.op3: Switch from one variable to another variable
data.op4: To choose from multiple possibilities which may arise due to different values of a single variable

data.question: Study the following ‘C’ program #include <stdio.h> void main () { static a, b; while (a > b ++) }
A labeled statement consist of an identifier followed by a
If the following loop is implemented void main() { int num = 0; do { - - num; printf (“%d”, num); num ++; } while (num >=0); }
data.op1: run time error will be reported
data.op2: The program will not enter into the loop
data.op3: The loop will run infinitely many times
data.op4: There will be a compilation error reported

data.question: Consider the following code snippet marks = 80; switch (marks) { case 60: grade = ‘C’; break; case 70: grade = ‘B’; break; case 80: grade = ‘A’; break; default: grade = ‘E’; } What is the value of ‘grade’ after the switch statement is executed?
Consider the following program fragment: switch (input) { case ‘1’: printf (“one”); case ‘3’: printf (“three”); case ‘4’: printf (“five”); default: printf (“odd”); break; }
Consider the following code fragment for(digit = 0; digit < 9; digit++) { digit = 2*digit; digit - -; }
The following program segment { int sum, index; index = 50; while (index > = 0) { sum =sum/index; -index; } }
data.op1: Will give a run time error
